posts.name: Noah LazerBeams
posts.cooked:
I’ve been trying to get MAXMotion position control working for a while now. Everything else works. MAXMotion velocity control? Beautiful. Regular closed loop position? Amazing. But for some reason whenever I set a reference to a goal using ControlType.kMAXMotionPositionControl, it doesn’t do anything. It just stares. Menacingly. I’d really like to understand why. I tried resetting the SparkMax. No dice.  

Here’s the code I’ve been running:  
[Link to NoahLacks/MAXMotionTest](https://github.com/NoahLacks/MAXMotionTest/tree/main/src/main/java/frc/robot)  

And this is how REV’s example affected things: MAXMotion velocity control now just stutters in place. And MAXMotion position control still does nothing.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Correct, MaxPosition isn't a reliable tool because it lacks the ability to integrate feed-forward information, which is crucial for accurate motion profiling. CD is mentioned for reasons related to its inner workings, but the key takeaway is to avoid it and opt for ProfilePID or utilize a TrapezoidalProfile with a PID target. As a team, it's unfortunate that this functionality isn't more dependable.

posts.name: Noah LazerBeams
posts.cooked: The text was cleaned up by removing the HTML tags and restructuring the sentences to form a coherent paragraph while preserving the original meaning. Minimal changes were made to improve readability and grammar.

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: We have it working on our robot it's reliable but not very intuitive to implement and we needed to add an I term to prevent oscillation. We wish you could incorporate feed forward. Figure out how to do it like @tekdemo suggested unless you require immediate functionality. Our code implementation is available here. Frankly we need a more effective solution.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
It’s not that it doesn’t work in theory—it does—but several implementation details it doesn’t handle are important and can cause issues. A new version fixes some problems but still struggles with optimal feedforward handling for tracking, particularly kv and ka. It relies on feedback, leading to instability in certain situations, requiring I and D terms for stability.

The WPILib profile tools don’t generate detailed trajectories like PathPlanner+choreo but recalculate motion in real-time within constraints. This allows better compensation for disturbances. Unlike simpler models, a trapezoidal single actuator setup is efficient enough for the Rio. We’ve implemented a streamlined command using Wpilib feed-forwards and onboard rev PID. Success stories suggest its effectiveness, aiding those who need guidance.

One issue is needing to duplicate the armgoal line between execute and start blocks to prevent incorrect trigger comparisons based on last goals. This affects functionality but doesn’t impact control loops, though it may confuse users without debounce mechanisms.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: You're not salty. It's a problem, just one of the reasons why teams like the CTRE software stack.

After reading 2910’s thread, I noticed they aren’t using feedforward with motion magic this year, instead opting for max motion on CTE devices—at least, as far as I can tell. Is max motion really that bad? Additionally, suggesting a Profiled PID Controller sounds promising since it uses a trapezoidal profile without feedforwards, especially when running on the Rio at slower speeds.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Look at the number of motors 2910 has on each mechanism. If you add enough power to make the feedforward only a fraction of a volt, it matters a lot less.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: AvocadoPeel asked, "Is Max Motion really that bad?" Another user responded, suggesting that feedforward isn't needed when using a trapezoidal profile, advising to use existing libraries instead of implementing it manually. A detailed explanation was given, including a Java code snippet for a PID controller, where feedforward voltage is calculated based on velocity differences. Questions were raised about control inputs and system stability, noting that delays due to Java's GC pauses necessitate motor controller feedback for stability.

posts.name: Noah LazerBeams
posts.cooked:
MAXMotion is problematic for two primary reasons.  
- No feedforward  
- It doesn’t function well for me  

Additionally, current practices involve:  
1. Calculating feedforward and applying a trapezoidal profile to the rio before sending the setpoint to the closed-loop controller.  
2. Disliking closed-loop systems; prefer handling everything directly on the rio.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: I think that MaxMotion is bad because

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked:
I added a fix to your code by adding the following line after line 54 in `ClosedLoopTestConstants.java`: `.positionMode(MAXMotionPositionMode.kMAXMotionTrapezoidal);`

Regarding your motor settings, I found that increasing your maxVelocity and maxAcceleration could improve performance. Currently set to 360 and 180 respectively, try raising these values. For instance, my maxAcceleration is 7500 and maxVelocity is 2000000, with maxVelocity stabilizing around 200000 after testing.

Additionally, consider refining your PID control parameters. Since switching to kMaxPosition required adjusting P values, I recommend updating your `.pidf` configuration in `kMotorConfig.encoder` to use only P, I, and D values by replacing `.pidf` with `.pid`. This adjustment resolved issues similar to those you encountered initially.

The key success factor was implementing the recommended line after line 54, which leverages trapezoidal PID movement for smoother operation.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: To test your velocity and acceleration set points, graph your mechanism's acceleration and velocity to verify if they meet your targets. If your targets exceed the velocity and acceleration plots, your mechanism cannot achieve them, or your constants are improperly set.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Whoever at REV considered RPM/s a suitable unit of acceleration needs to explain why such a unit was deemed appropriate. For instance, the author mentions having a maxAcceleration of 7500 and maxVelocity of 2000000, beyond which the system stopped adjusting its speed incrementally.

posts.cooked: Eh, I’d argue Phoenix 5 units were worse.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
We used MaxMotion on the elevator and arm this year. The elevator had an arb feedforward added after a regional setting. Some tips from our experiences include:

- If it isn’t moving, ensure max acceleration is set sufficiently high, checking for unit mismatches.
- You can monitor output voltage to verify how much motion is applied. Previous issues arose from incorrect conversions between rpm and rpm/s, requiring multiplication by a conversion factor.
- We utilized a relative throughbore encoder for the elevator and an absolute throughbore encoder for the arm to maintain consistent unit configurations.
- The proportional (kP) value was generally insensitive, working well across a wide operational range.
- To address endpoint jitter, we implemented error tolerance, settling on 4 mm for elevator tolerance.
